How are ratings calculated?
To calculate the overall star rating and percentage breakdown by star, we don’t use a simple average. Instead, our system considers things like how recent a review is and if the reviewer bought the item on Amazon. It also analyzes reviews to verify trustworthiness.

Chris Seitz
4.0 out of 5 stars V3 is an Upgrade and Downgrade to V2, but overall an amazing mouse.
Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2021
Size: MouseVerified Purchase
The V2 is amazing. I love it and have bought it multiple times.

The V3 improves on that by adding even more features, making it even better.

However, the sensitivity clutch button has been redesigned and it's a significant downgrade. It's not as easy to press like on the V2 and doesn't have as much tactile feedback. It used to be a lever attached to the mouse which works beautifully on the V2, but now it's a button. Plus, the V3 clutch isn't removable unlike on the V2, so you couldn't even replace it if you wanted to.

If you've never used the V2, definitely buy the V3. If you've used the V2, the V3 will mildly irritate you enough to keep using your V2.

I used the sensitivity clutch as my hypershift key to remap all my other keybinds momentarily, and I cannot rely on this new button in FPS games. I'll be sticking with my V2 when playing anything that requires quick actions.

Customer 2021
1.0 out of 5 stars Contains TROJAN Malware
Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2021
Size: MouseVerified Purchase
Update - three days in the left mouse button has developed a double detent click on rebound. Press, click, released - click-CLICK. Very strong and very annoying. Right button still working as expected. So the mouse has mechanically failed after a few days of use.

Add this mechanical failure to the trojan software issue -- time for this mouse to go back to sender, no replacement needed.

Only after plugging in the mouse was I made aware the Razor Mouse is notorious for its MALWARE.

Microsoft immediately flagged the offending code, but the damage had already been done. Apparently a well known security issue in the IT industry, the Razor Mouse imitates a keyboard and types in commands bypassing PC security - allowing it to install any software it wants without user intervention and before you even agree to the install.

And the problem goes with the mouse: anything you plug it into is infected. Worse, any computer where you have plugged in the mouse and the trojan ware was installed now forces you to deal with the trojan popping up any time you plus most USB devices into that computer.

Absolutely amazing any company would do this -- and there are hints this trojan is being used to bypass system security in military installations. Also points to a Microsoft Windows problem - that any hardware can do this is just amazingly stupid.

Jesse Henderson
4.0 out of 5 stars Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
Size: MouseVerified Purchase
When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:

TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good. But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.

Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).

Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.

I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.

The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.

Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.

With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.

5.0 out of 5 stars No more scroll dead spots!
Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2021
Size: MouseVerified Purchase
I loved the V2 version of this mouse except for one major downfall: my V2 had dead spots every 180 degrees (twice per revolution) on the scroll wheel where a 'tick' of the scroll wheel did not actually register. This was infuriating at times. You tried to switch weapons, but nothing happened. You tried to select the next record in a drop down list, but nope! The V3 does not have this problem. The scroll wheel also has a lot of mass to it so you can fling it (even without it unlocked) and it will continue a little while, while the V2 stopped almost instantly. It is also nice to have the button fixed to the side instead of using the magnetic lever.

Top reviews from other countries

CHORIZO
4.0 out of 5 stars Great mouse for the right person
Reviewed in Canada on September 20, 2021
Size: MouseVerified Purchase
This is the most ergonomically shaped mouse for right handed users in Razer's lineup, and it directly competes with Logitech's G502. With the V3 and the new scroll wheel that can be toggled between clicks and free spin mode, Razer has finally managed to match the G502 for productivity. Before you buy, I would recommend you check if the mouse shape matches what you're currently using.

The reasons I chose to pay for a V3 at full price versus a discounted V2 were

1. V3 uses Razer's new v2 optical switches. Older Basilisks uses original optical switches that had very loose tolerances, which lead to the many complaints about loose buttons and mushy clicks across the entirety of Razer's lineup. This is the thing that is probably worth paying more for. I have no idea if later revisions of say the Basilisk Ultimate fixed this, as Razer did stealth fix it for their Viper Ultimate lineup.
2. Better scroll wheel. This is probably subjective (more on this later), but the idea of allowing free spin or even using a hybrid switch between the two appealed to me over your average clicky scrolls. It also clicks left or right, not that I can really think of a good use for it personally.
3. A built in DPI clutch button. I don't think I'll actually be using it, but seems like it doesn't ship with V2 by default and people end up losing it all the time as it's just magnetically attached.
4. RGB. I'm not big on RGB, my case is a Define R5 sitting under the table, out of sight and out of mind, but since my keyboard does have some and my previous budget mouse had it, fancy RGB is definitely appreciated. Seriously, it looks so good.

The drawbacks versus the V2s though

1. V3 is heavier by about 10g or so, but at this weight category you probably don't care. If you do then look to the Viper Ultimate instead.
2. V2 features a scroll wheel whose resistance can be adjusted manually. I personally think the V3's clicky mode is a little bit too hard to scroll, to the point where if I applied enough force to go up I end up clicking it down as a middle mouse button. I would've liked to adjust the resistance ever so slightly.

The new wheel got mixed reviews across the web. I didn't find it loose or difficult to use overall, but there is a very audible click when swapping between clicky and free scroll. When using Razer Synapse you can have auto unlock to free spin if you scroll fast, but I feel like it triggers too soon, personally, and would like to see a way to tweak the threshold in software. I just left it off and I'm going to keep it in clicky mode, which kinda negates the advantage of this new wheel for me.

If you are gaming, then you have some other choices from Razer's lineup, such as the Viper and Deathadder V2. The Basilisk is probably the LARGEST and HEAVIEST mouse in their lineup. In my experience it is more suitable for large hands (I would say mine is medium) in a palm grip, as otherwise in claw or finger grip you're not likely to be able to reach the thumb clutch button.

It is also ergonamically shaped - and believe it or not, this was actually a minus for me. I am used to playing on symmetrical, almost ambidextrous mice, so I tend to lay my wrist down flat. With the Basilisk I am forced to twist my wrist at at least a 45 degree angle - which is the point of an ergonomic mouse, after all, but it was not very comfortable (right now) compared to what I was used to. Plus, because of the mouse shape, my palm rests on it at a different pressure point - more like under the index finger, where as I prefer to have support under my middle and ring finger area when I hold down right click to aim down the sights in FPS. Both of these combined meant I ended up feeling like my fingers are cramped at the end of a gaming session, even though this mouse has a wide grip and rubber sides that in theory should be more comfortable. I'm sure I could adapt to this over time, as I was a palm gripper years ago, but this is where I decided to look for a different mouse in Razer's lineup instead.

One last concern - I have reservations about the longevity of the injection molded rubber grips on either side of the mouse. I'm sure it's fine for me, but it is the reason why my friend refuses to buy another Razer mouse with it (the viper mini doesn't have these, so he got that instead). If you swap mouse every couple of years anyway (Razer's warranty period) then it's probably fine.

Logitech offers more popular alternatives as well, but every single Logitech mice I've had started double clicking, and this is true for every single person I knew - so I'm not buying a Logitech until they figure out a more durable switch. As well, Razer's optical switches allows them to have the fastest click latency compared to the competition. If you're buying 144+hz monitors to get that edge in competitive FPS, then you should probably invest in a fancy mouse with minimal click latency. Check out Youtubers like Optimum Tech for more information.
